page.title: 11Ecology, Scoutmoor.
page.content: These exposed moorlands are developed on underlying millstone grit rocks, quite unique to the{Pennines.}The stone is used to make the black dry-stone walls used as field boundaries. Being on the windward side of the Pennines the area is exposed to wet, westerly winds and this, coupled with an average altitude of 300 metres, results in wet, windy and cold conditions. The water-table is at or near the surface and so feels wet and marshy under-foot. The soils are very acid and support only moorland vegetation such as heather, gorse and ling. Grass is tufted are coarse broken by an occasional shrub or small tree. This rugged, but unspoilt, terrain is popular with ramblers and conservationalists alike and has a beauty of its own.
